title: Is the expression, 'in contrast' correct, or should we say, 'in contrast to'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the question. The answer depends on what comes before. Obviously, if you’re talking about a contrast, there need to be two things that are contrasted with each other. One of them may be implied because it was mentioned just before. If you use “in contrast”without further qualification, you need to have specified the other item of contrast previously. E.g., “Around this latitude, every autumn the leaves on most trees change color and fall off. In contrast, the leaves of tropical plants stay green all year.” “In contrast” applied to the tropical plants would not make any sense if you hadn’t brought up deciduous trees in the first sentence. The other version, “in contrast to” fits best when the two items are both brought up within the one sentence. E.g., “In contrast to the Western use of knives and forks, many people from the Far East prefer to eat with chopsticks.”

Both are correct; rather, it’s the grammatical structure they should appear in that differs. Trying to avoid grammatical jargon, the standard structures are as follows:— In contrast to (some particular thing, described without using a full sentence), (full sentence about something contrasting).e.g.: “In contrast to (dogs), (cats hate water).” “In contrast to (all my previous dogs), (my new dog turned out to be lazy).” “In contrast to (my mother’s attitude to marmalade), (I can’t stand the stuff).” 2. (Previous full sentence about something.) In contrast, (full sentence about something contrasting). e.g. “(Most cats hate water.) In contrast, (many dogs love swimming).” “(My new dog turned out to be lazy.) In contrast, (all my previous dogs have been dynamite).” “(I can’t stand marmalade.) In contrast, (my mother adored it).”

Both are fine . When you use 'in contrast,' you should have mentioned something in the previous sentance that you are going to contrast with now. When you use in contrast to, neither of the contrasting phenomena may yet have been mentioned and you will be talking about both of them or at least about one of them later in the sentence. Example: I am moody and irritable. In contrast, my brother is cheerful and tolerant. In contrast to my moodiness, my brother's cheerfullness stands out.

Both expressions are correct depending on the context. If you are comparing two things and you start by talking about the first, then you can use 'in contrast to the first item, the second is…’ or you can directly say 'In contrast, the second item is…’. The latter usage is usually used in the beginning of a sentence.

Answer: Both are correct. Examples: (source: Use in contrast in a sentence — yourdictionary) “In contrast, courts of law apply the law to everyone.”“The climatic conditions of the south are in contrast to those of the north.

Both expressions are used for different situations. E.g. I am easily excitable. In contrast, my sister is a calm, level-headed person. E.g. In contrast to my calm, level-headed sister, I am easily excitable.
